keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family reported he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up'.
Cagle was not armed at the time of arrest but an AR-15 assault rifle was found in his vehicle outside the airport.

He faces multiple state and federal charges including terroristic threats, attempted aggravated assault, possession of a firearm in commission of a felony, and being a convicted felon in possession of a firearm.
Cagle has a prior conviction for marijuana possession over two decades ago and is currently without legal representation.
The FBI is assisting in the investigation, and officials emphasized that the situation was a 'tragedy averted' due to early detection by family and law enforcement.
The airport is the busiest in the world with over 108 million passengers in 2024, making the incident particularly significant in terms of public safety.
Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens noted that Cagle had a semi-automatic weapon and was mentally challenged, which combined could have led to a deadly outcome.
Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem expressed gratitude that the individual was apprehended before any harm occurred.
The event highlights the importance of community vigilance and early reporting in preventing mass violence at high-traffic locations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at the world’s busiest airport, Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, after his family alerted authorities that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up'. Although not armed at the time of arrest, an AR-15 assault rifle was found in his vehicle. Cagle faces multiple state and federal charges, including terroristic threats, attempted aggravated assault, and being a convicted felon in possession of a firearm. Authorities, including Atlanta Police Chief Darin Schierbaum and Mayor Andre Dickens, stressed that the situation was averted due to timely community vigilance. The FBI is assisting in the investigation. The incident underscores the risks of combining mental health issues, firearm access, and public threat communication, especially at high-traffic locations like major international airports. Federal officials, including Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem, acknowledged the event as a success in preventing a tragedy.
title: Man arrested inside Atlanta airport after making threats to ‘shoot it up’
